displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know the paperwork that we usually do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The, it, the biggest side effect can be dropping of blood counts. So what you’re gonna have to do… Doctor: No. The best way to prevent it is we will give you a shot the second day, okay, the day after your chemo to um help prevent the blood counts from dropping. Patient: So this will be the last chemo? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: For this particular one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then next time we’ll start the new one. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay and that will be uh so you’ll have to come two days in a row every three weeks.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

Patient: I want the best of what the best is for. Doctor: Yeah, No, I know. Patient: you know. Doctor: Well, but you’re a guy that doesn’t you know sit around. I mean part of the thing that we wanted to do earlier this year was just like knock out what you can knock out which you did. So, I’m sorry that we’re at this point but let’s not be sorry, let’s just do something about it. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so, are you due for a shot today? Patient: I don’t know. The last one I had was in June. Doctor: Okay, I think you are so I’m gonna give this to J____ so we can just get everything on one paper because I don’t want to lose track of your next injection either. So, your Lupron stays in the background, we fart around with all this. Patient: Well, I took that in, Lupron and then all this. Doctor: In June or August? Oh, do I give you the Lupron? Oh, I don’t, Patient: No, Dr___ I had went to him in August. Doctor: okay. That’s why I don’t know, got it, yep. Patient: And I go back I think it’s in March. He gave me a six month shot this time.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.None: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::None

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Yeah, okay, okay. Doctor: So I think we should just reschedule for next Thursday, the shot on Friday and that’s that. Patient: Okay, okay. Reschedule what for next Thursday? Family Member: Chemo. Doctor: Chemo. Patient: Oh and then have that follow-up shot on Friday? Doctor: Correct. Patient: Okay. Um a couple quick questions though. Doctor: Okay. Patient: You’ve still got time? Doctor: Yeah shoot. Patient: Okay um are they not coming in to video tape? Doctor: They are. They’re videoing right now. Say hi! Wave it will go up and down. They see us.

Patient: Okay. (Pause4sec) Patient: It’s just what I do to deal with the cancer. Doctor: Chew gum. Patient: Okay. Can’t stand it. Doctor: Hmmm? Patient: Oh, I hope my teeth can stand it. (sighs) Doctor: Okay. So we saw you the beginning of April. How you feeling? Patient: Okay. Uh, I guess about five o’clock in the afternoon, uh I run out of gas. Doctor: Uh, runs out of gas. Uh, so, what does that mean? You have to take a nap or you just -- ? Patient: I have to, I have to sit. I did mow the grass, but, um, it gets. Patient: Nope. I don’t do much at all. Doctor: And what are you missin’ out on?

Patient: What do you mean I won’t be - Healthcare Professional: D____ doesn’t start um - Doctor: Wait, he doesn’t have Healthcare Professional: Yeah, I was going to put a sticker up there. D____ doesn’t start I.V.’s; she can only draw blood. Patient: No? Family Member: Yes. Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that.

Healthcare Professional: It’s really so I don’t forget it later. Doctor: Okay, we’re having a good discussion. They were afraid I was gonna give them a quiz at the end of it but I think we’re good. Healthcare Professional: Alright, I promise not to, no, I probably shouldn’t promise I won’t interrupt again. Doctor: Of course you won’t. Family Member: So, if it’s bone only after the scans, Doctor: Yeah Family Member: it’s radium for sure? Doctor: Well, it’s radium as an option. You know, you guys might look at that and go um, I don’t know how I feel about it and after you talk to the radiation doctor who administers it, you know, some people might say oh, gosh, I just worried about it and I’d rather take chemo and that’s okay too. I’m just trying to make it so easy. I mean any and all of this is interchangeable. If you had just bone only, you could get chemo Patient: Okay. Doctor: but if you have not just bone you can’t get radium. So, radium is only good for one thing. You got bone you can get radium. Patient: Radium. Doctor: It can’t go anywhere else. So, if it’s anywhere else other than bone, no go on the radium. Taxotere, you know, chemo could be anywhere anytime, less picky. Patient: What happened to the radiation that I took for the forty some days? Whatever did that do any good or it did nothing or what?

Family Member: If it’s okay with you, I mean… Doctor: Yeah it’s okay with me. Family Member: He’s a good guy. Doctor: Uh huh, Yeah I think he’s excellent. I haven’t talked to him in a long time, but he and I are close. We used to talk all the time. Family Member: Okay. Gives you a good reason for you to get back together (Laughs) Doctor: M____. Family Member: He’s at M___ because I worked there. Doctor: That used to be C____> Family Member: Yeah. Patient: Mm,hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Will you make your own appointment with him? Family Member: I can. I mean whatever I need to do, just let me know. I’ll do it. (pause)

Patient: Because he went on to say he says in that area… Doctor: Um hum. Patient: …and we probably will be looking at some radiation. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And you know me, or like anyone, you’re going through the chemo and stuff like that you want… Doctor: Yeah. You’re like whaaaat? Patient: You want the golden ring man. Doctor: I got ya. Patient: You want that stuff to be doing everything it’s supposed to do. Doctor: Yeah. Right. Well it is doing everything it’s supposed to do because if you look at your lymph node, remember the bones hardly ever change. Patient: Right. Doctor: So whether it’s up or down, I just want to know if it’s new.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do. Doctor: I know. Patient: Yes, I do. Doctor: Gee, you and every other guy I have in my practice which is why I say this. Patient: Oh, Okay. Doctor: Please just recognize that your quality of life will be so much better Patient: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Even at one or two scans are unlikely to be positive. Patient: Right. Doctor: I’m not having a lot of good luck telling you what’s average. Family Member: He seems to be the Patient: But even you know the PSA values I think you mentioned at one of the previous meetings you know in of itself the value itself wouldn’t have – my – the only thing was the trending and I get that part of it because you had mentioned you’ve seen it in points to where you know some people would be an eleven, you know that was a signal on that one, but for it to be a three and a half or something like that one you know the number alone you know it didn’t… Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Yeah I’ve showed your case in a conference and everybody was like oh my God. Family Member: Um hum. lucky Patient: When do I meet him? Doctor: Not for a long time. Patient: Ladies and gentlemen your test subject. (Laughter) Doctor: Okay I’m gonna talk to J____ about getting these arrangements –

Patient: Mmm, hmm. Doctor: Because I know you’ll never call me if you’re getting sick from the medicine. Patient: Oh! I’ll call! Doctor: No, you won’t! Patient: Yeah. I’ll call. Well, like I said, I started getting that pain in my hip last week, but I knew I was coming here today to see you, and I said I’ll just wait until I go in. But, yeah, it was getting kind of, it was startin’ to hurt. Doctor: Getting tough. Patient: Yeah. You remember when you did all that biopsy there. Right in this area, right here. Doctor: So, that tells me that the cancer is growing in there primarily. Patient: Mmm…hmmm. Doctor: Which may mean I’d have to do radiation to that area. Patient: Wowwww. Okay. Doctor: Because that is a joint that we have to put our weight on

Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’ve amended it and added a new cohort, so another group of men. But, these are men that they’re last therapy, or their willingness to stay on Enzalutamide, because there’s one group, uh, that showed that maybe if you use Enzalutamide and immune therapy, you get a better response (chuckles) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, we’re testing a group of men, uh, uh, with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Is that just starting? Doctor: Uh, that has been open probably for a couple of months. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it has a lot of rules. Either, you have to be AR-V7 positive. So, we would have to draw a tube of blood. Uh, and that we can do. Uh, it takes a week to come back. If you scream positive with that as positive, then the team could talk to you about the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. If you’re negative, then you’re not eligible from the get-go.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …we tend to treat it systemically. Patient: Okay. Doctor: …with pills or IV or whatnot which we’ll talk about. So I don’t want to cut you open, but I do want to re-biopsy you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um and I talked to our radiologist. He’s gonna see at the time that you’re on the table of the CAT scan what is the best area to target because these things all move as well. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Preferably the largest one because it’s an easier target, but we want to make sure that one, it’s safe for you. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Number two, that we can get enough samples. So here the ‘enough’ means that we’d like to get some stuff for testing? Patient: Right. Doctor: Just regular hey what’s on the pathology? Patient: Mhmm.
